timeline.bodyText: comment.. no need for 2 dot at the end
timeline.author: strkkk

revised_code.chunk:
diff --git a/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/JavadocTagContinuationIndentationCheck.java b/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/JavadocTagContinuationIndentationCheck.java index 1a3e0997f..0788c4328 100644 --- a/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/JavadocTagContinuationIndentationCheck.java +++ b/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/JavadocTagContinuationIndentationCheck.java @@ -50,12 +50,15 @@ import com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.utils.JavadocUtil; * 
  * <module name="JavadocTagContinuationIndentation"/>
  *
+ *

+ * Example: + *

* 
  * /**
- *  * @tag comment..
- *  *  Indentation spacing is 1 (violation)
- *  *   Indentation spacing is 2 (violation)
- *  *     Indentation spacing is 4 (OK)
+ *  * @tag comment
+ *  *  Indentation spacing is 1 // violation
+ *  *   Indentation spacing is 2 // violation
+ *  *     Indentation spacing is 4 // OK
  *  */
  * public class Test {
  * }

timeline.bodyText:
(violation) -> // violation
Here and in other cases below
timeline.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText:
@strkkk  examples of other Javadoc checks have the format (violation)....should I still change it to // violation ?
The same is for OK--> (OK)
replies.author: DXTkastb

replies.bodyText:
What checks do you mean?
Most of checks have this format // violation, so it is better to keep it consistent
replies.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText: @strkkk Some Checks in Javadoc Comments have this format
replies.author: DXTkastb

replies.bodyText:
yes, but some have no format at all...
Lets do it like in most other javadoc checks, like
/**
* Line with violation
* OK line
*/

without parens and slashes
replies.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText: I don't know if its a problem or some misunderstanding on my part but this check does not show violations for identation  >= offset. Please confirm this. Also if it's not a problem, then I think it should be added to documentation as there is nothing mentioned about this.
replies.author: DXTkastb

replies.bodyText:
What do you mean? Is it a case when indentation should be 2, but in fact it is 4 results in no violation?
If it is, you can check test inputs for cases like this. If there are some, you can see how it works. In case there are none, issue can be created.
replies.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText: @strkkk yes, it does not show violations, Issue #2813 is about this problem.
replies.author: DXTkastb

replies.bodyText:
(sigh)
Ok, please ignore this item then, I was not aware of this issue
replies.author: strkkk
